Award.AwardTitle: 2016 Summer Program at Center for Theoretical Underground Physics and Related Areas (CETUP*)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for the sixth CETUP* (Center for Theoretical Underground Physics and Related Areas) summer program that is planned to take place on June 6 - July 16, 2016 in Lead/Deadwood, SD. The main goal of CETUP* is to bring together people with different expertise to address the most exciting questions in particle and nuclear physics, astrophysics, cosmology and geosciences. This year's program will focus on Dark Matter, Neutrino Physics and Unification, bringing together experts in dark matter, neutrino physics, particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics and cosmology.

Basic research impacts many areas of science and technology. In particular, understanding neutrino properties better could have significant implications in astrophysics and cosmology, and may offer solutions to the current puzzles such as the abundance of matter over antimatter, and better knowledge of the potential connections between new fundamental particles will allow the determination of their impact on the early universe. The CETUP* program will offer a stimulating environment for research collaborations between scientists of varying ages and nationalities and the training of young scientists, including undergraduate and graduate students and under-represented groups. The award will provide travel support for the early career scientists and students to participate in this summer program.

Scientists invited to participate in the program will not only provide theoretical support to the underground science, but they will also examine the underlying universal questions including: What is the nature of dark matter? What is the origin of neutrino masses? How have neutrinos shaped the evolution of the universe? How were the elements from iron to uranium made in the early universe? What is the origin and thermal history of the Earth? How do supernovae explode? What is the origin of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the Universe? What are the fundamental underlying symmetries of the Universe? and Is there a Grand Unified Theory of the Universe? The 2016 CETUP* will consist of a 6-week long program. The two-week long session on Physics and Instrumentation of the Near Detector for the Long-Baseline Neutrino Experiments will be followed by the two-week long Neutrino Physics/Unification session: "From Grand Unification to String Theory and Back" and the program will end with a two-week long session on Dark Matter.

Project Outcomes Report:

Initiated in 2007 at Texas A&M University (TAMU), College Station, TX, the International Conference on Interconnections between Particle Physics and Cosmology is a unique venue that targets well-motivated connections between these two areas. Over last ten years PPC meetings were held at such places like Torino (Italy), CERN (Geneva, Switzerland), Seoul (S. Korea), Deadwood (SD, USA), Leon (Mexico), Sao Paulo (Brazil). The XIth International Conference on Interconnections between Particle Physics and Cosmology (PPC2017) returned to Texas, and was hosted by Texas A&M University – Corpus Christi during May 22-26, 2017.

PPC2017 was intend to bring together approximately hundred international experts in particle and nuclear physics, cosmology and astrophysics and allow for intellectual integration and the fruitful exchange of ideas in a dynamic atmosphere of intense scientific interactions. The conference aimed at providing a stimulating environment for experts in these different fields that allowed addressing major theoretical models, current experimental data, the upcoming future experiments, and future possible experiments and accelerators that are at the proposal stage. Discussion of results from recent neutrino experiments and observations, direct and indirect dark matter detection experiments, detection of gravitational waves, data from particle colliders, Grand Unified Theories and their implications, as well as subjects related to early and late universe cosmology, baryogenesis and many others were an integral part of PPC 2017. The scientific topics covered by PPC 2017 not only advanced the knowledge in particle and nuclear physics, astrophysics and cosmology but also explored new physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics and explored the connection between particle physics and cosmology. This effort required integration of intellectual leaders in diverse fields from around the world and provided a stimulating venue for exchange of scientific ideas among experts in in dark matter, unification, neutrino physics, particle physics, nuclear physics and astrophysics.

PPC 2017 consisted of 59 scientific talks presented during sixteen plenary sessions, two summery talks on Particle Physics and Cosmology and 20 talks presented during the parallel sessions and now archived on the PPC website: http://sci.tamucc.edu/events/ppc/. 97 international scientists attended the conference representing Brazil, Chile, China, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Turkey, UK, USA. Among the attendees, there were 11 graduate students, 17 postdocs, 2 instructors, 24 assistant professors, 35 associate and full professors, 8 lab researchers.

An important component of the PPC mission is to provide educational outreach opportunity extended to local community and communicate the importance of dark matter, neutrino research, and support of investment in science education to the public. During PPC2017 two Nobel Laureates – Prof. David Gross and Adam Riess – met with middle and high school students, undergraduate and graduate students as well as general public during two free of charge forums. 'Dream of Solving the Mysteries of the Universe with Nobel Prize Winners - David Gross and Adam Riess' attracted over 900 attendees who actively participated in the lectures, Q&A sessions and discussions. It was first time in the history of Corpus Christi and TAMU-CC to host such prominent guests. Both outreach events had a tremendous impact on our community emphasizing the importance of education and STEM.
